DOC.HEAD: Two More Servicemen Killed In Panama Returned to Dover Air Force Base
With AM-Panama-Wounded
DOC.TEXT: The bodies of two more U.S. servicemen killed in Panama were returned to Dover Air Force Base on Christmas Day, the 22nd and 23rd since the U.S. invasion began last week. The bodies were flown aboard a transport plane from Howard Air Force Base in Panama and unloaded about 2 a.m., officials at the Delaware base said. The two were identified as Army Chief Warrant Officer 2 Andrew P. Porter, 25, of St. Clair, Mich., and Army Pfc. James A. Tabor Jr., 18, of Montrose, Colo. Porter was based at Fort Ord, Calif., and Tabor was based at Fort Bragg, N.C. The body of another serviceman flown to Dover early Saturday was identified as 1st Lt. John R. Hunter, 30, of Victor, Mont. Hunter was based at Fort Campbell, Ky. and was an Army helicopter crewman. The remains of those killed are being brought to Dover Air Force Base to be prepared for burial before being transferred to their next of kin. The base houses the Defense Department's largest mortuary.
